questions.text: Windshield impact to front seat passenger may impact which among the following injuries

questions.text: Which of the following is a frequent type of injury seen in tertiary impact injuries?
Which of the following is a classic pattern of injury seen in pedestrian children involved in road traffic accidents?
questions.explanation:
Injuries
  • Occur when the victim is struck by the vehicle, often following recognizable patterns.
  • Common injuries include abrasions, lacerations, fractures of legs, thighs, or buttocks, and fractures of the fibula and tibia.
  • When an adult is hit by a car, the impact is often at knee level, and injuries vary depending on the victim’s position and vehicle orientation.
  • Common cause of death is due to head injury and fracture dislocation of cervical spine, mainly at the atlanto-occipital joint.

Factors influencing injury behavior include
  • Position of the victim's feet (whether they were firmly placed or raised at impact).
  • Speed of the vehicle (low speed results in being thrown onto the bonnet; at higher speeds, the victim is projected or scooped up).
  • Road surface type (smooth, rough, gravel).
  • Point of impact relative to the center of gravity.
  • When the pedestrian is knocked down from behind with both feet fixed to the ground, there will be fracture of the bones of the lower limbs.

Waddell's Triad

A classic pattern in pedestrian children struck by vehicles.

  • Fractured femoral shaft.
  • Intrathoracic or intra-abdominal injuries.
  • Contralateral head injury.

Injury Behavior Based on Position and Vehicle Impact

On Being struck from behind with feet not firmly on the ground:

  • The victim’s feet are thrown backwards.
  • Possible head injuries from striking against the windscreen.
  • Victims can be scooped up or fall to one side, sustaining further head injuries from striking the ground.

 

Struck from the front:

  • Injuries to chest, abdomen, with potential fractures of ribs or vertebrae.
  • Pelvic or sacroiliac fractures, as well as fractures of the tibia or fibula from bumper impact.
 

Bumper impact injuries:

  • Soft tissue damage and fractures (typically wedge-shaped).
  • Fractures may suggest the point of impact and movement direction of the vehicle.
  • The location and measurement of the bumper fracture on the victim provide details about the vehicle's height and speed.
  • Wedge type bumper fracture of the tibia seen.

 
  • Marks may suggest if the victim was walking or lying on the road when struck.
 

When the pedestrian walks into the side of a moving vehicle

  • Glancing abrasions
  • Crushing lacerations on the side or front of the face, chest and arms.
  • Fracture of ribs with or without laceration.
  • Sustain secondary injuries
  • Fracture of the skull occurs due to direct impact of the vehicle on the head.

Which of the following statements accurately describes 'Hide and die' syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs when hypothermic victims discard their clothing due to overheating sensations

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by the victim pulling household items over themselves or hiding in unusual places, due to mental confusion from hypothermia

options.label: C
options.text: It refers to a skin condition caused by prolonged exposure to cold, resulting in ulcerative lesions

options.label: D
options.text: It is the result of an intentional attempt by victims to escape from a dangerous situation

questions.correct_answer: B. It is characterized by the victim pulling household items over themselves or hiding in unusual places, due to mental confusion from hypothermia
questions.explanation:
Definition

Core temperature below 36°C (96.8°F)

Signs
  • Disorientation
  • Dulling of consciousness
  • Loss of reflex
  • Fall in respiration, heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Red patches and pallor of the skin
  • Edema of the face
  • Stiffness of neck muscles

Autopsy findings
  • Patches of pink to brownish-pink discoloration
  • Postmortem staining: Pink/bright red
  • Cyanosis or pallor in extremities ("white deaths")
  • Edema of feet and blistering of skin
  • Stomach: Wischnewsky spots-brownish black colored gastric mucosal ulcers
  • Viscera-congested, hemorrhagic

Phenomena seen in hypothermia victims

  • Paradoxical undressing- found undressed due to disorientation which increases heat loss (mistaken for evidence of sexual assault or homicide) (Option A ruled out)
  • ‘Hide and die' syndrome- found in unusual locations resembling an attempt to "hide" or create a protective environment due to mental confusion and a possible hibernation reflex (confused with signs of homicide or robbery) (Option B)
  • Chilblain (Erythema Pernio)- red, itching skin lesions typically found on extremities due to cold exposure, often accompanied by edema and blistering.

options.text: Blisters filled with protein-rich fluid and soot in the upper respiratory tract

questions.correct_answer: B. Pugilistic attitude and blisters filled with clear fluid
questions.explanation:
Non specific findings in burns cases

Phenomenon

Description

Cause

Key Features

Medico-Legal Significance

Puppet Organs

Internal organs become shriveled, firm, and hardened by heat.

Prolonged exposure to high temperatures.

Organs resemble firm, "cooked" structures.

Shows prolonged heat exposure.

Heat Hematoma

Large artifact resembling extradural hematoma, containing 100–120 ml of blood.

Blood from longitudinal venous sinuses or diploic veins.

1.5 cm thick; the heat forces blood from calvarium through veins onto dura.

Resembles extradural hematoma.

Heat Ruptures

Skin splits resembling incised or lacerated wounds due to heat contraction of tissue.

Contraction of heated, coagulated tissue.

Fissures contain nerves, vessels, connective tissue; no clotted blood, irregular margins, no bruising.

Differentiates heat damage from violent injury.

Pugilistic Attitude

Flexed posture of arms and legs resembling a boxing stance.

Coagulation of muscle proteins and dehydration.

Flexor muscles contract more than extensors; seen in cremations.

No significance whether alive or dead pre-burn.

Heat Fractures

Fractures caused by heat, with long bones showing curved fractures.

Muscle shrinkage pulls on tendons and bones during exposure to high heat.

Heat fractures do not involve skull sutures; neurocranium remains as fragments up to 10 cm; hyoid can become fragile.

Identifies extreme heat exposure and helps distinguish heat fractures from trauma.

Heat Hematoma

Heat Ruptures

questions.text: A 7 year old child is admitted in ER with burns to the entire posterior trunk and the left lower limb. Using the Lund and Browder chart, calculate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) affected?
questions.explanation:
Body Surface Area Assessment in Children

(Lund and Browder Chart)

Baseline Percentages (Under 1 Year)
  • Head: 18% of Total Body Surface Area (TBSA)
  • Each Leg: 14% of TBSA
  • Trunk and Arms: Same as adult percentages

Age Adjustment Formula
  • For each year over age 1:
    • Add 0.5% to each leg
    • Subtract 1.0% from head
  • Continue adjustments until adult values are reached.

Example Calculation

For a 3-year-old child:

  • Start with baseline values
  • Adjust for 2 years (age 1 to 3):
    • Legs: 14% + (2 × 0.5%) = 15% each
    • Head: 18% - (2 × 1.0%) = 16%

options.label: B
options.text: Core body temperature of more than 40.5°C

questions.explanation:
Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Cramps (Miner’s/Stoker’s/Fireman’s Cramps)

Fluid and electrolyte depletion (dilutional hyponatremia), following vigorous activity and profuse sweating.
  • Sudden severe muscle cramps (arms, legs, abdomen)
  • Tender, hard, lumpy muscles
  • Flushed face, dilated pupils, dizziness, vomiting
  • Moist, cool skin, body temperature normal/slightly elevated

Non-specific

Heat Exhaustion

Prolonged strenuous activity with inadequate water/salt intake in a hot environment.
  • Nausea, vomiting, malaise, myalgia
  • CNS symptoms: dizziness, fatigue, impaired judgment, psychosis (severe water depletion)
  • Moist skin, increased pulse, rectal temperature > 37.8°C

Non-specific

Heat Stroke


 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure (Option C ruled out)

  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia

  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction
  • High fever

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding immersion syndrome and frostbite is false?

options.label: B
options.text: Pressure is applied in frostbite treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Dampness is required for immersion syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: Tetanus prophylaxis is given in frostbite cases with deep infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Pressure is applied in frostbite treatment
questions.explanation:
Condition

Cause

Symptoms

Treatment

Immersion Syndrome (Trench/Immersion Foot/Hand)

Prolonged exposure to severe cold (<10ºC) and dampness (common in warfare, trenches, or sea immersion)(Option C ruled out)
  • Affects extremities (feet, hands) (Option A ruled out)
  • Cold, numbness, burning, cyanosis

Air drying, protecting extremities from trauma and infection, gradual rewarming by air exposure at room temperature (avoid heat, massaging, or moistening the skin)

Frostbite

 

Exposure to extreme cold (-2.5ºC), causing tissue freezing and blood supply obstruction

Blue-black disco No loration of fingers, toes, nose, ears, face.

  • Mild cases: numbness, prickling.
  • Severe cases: paresthesia, stiffness, necrosis, gangrene, edema, blisters.
  • Rewarming:
    • For superficial frostbite (frostnip): Firm steady pressure is applied with a warm hand (without rubbing), by placing fingers in the armpits and for the feet, by covering with dry socks
    • For deep frostbite: Frozen extremity is immersed for several minutes in a moving water bath, heated to 40–42°C, until the distal tip of the part being thawed, flushes
  • Pressure or friction is avoided (Option B)
  • Anti-infective measures: Tetanus prophylaxis and antibiotics for deep infection (Option D ruled out)
